title: (x) Quince logo w/ swirly initial and classic serif caps - (similar to) Shango {Rainer}
content:
Can you whizes ID the two fonts used for this logo?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Quince logo.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202050153/http:/typophile.com/files/Quince%20logo.png) | 8.26 KB |
author: ignatiusx

comments.content: Shango or Schneidler Initials for the serif. The Q looks like done by hand.

I think the Q is not a font. The serif is unusual in that the U is not contrasted. Golden Cockerel Initials is like this, but the C and E don't match. I seem to recall that some Gill serifs may have had this sort of U, but I need to look more.

- Mike Yanega

Shango has a number of alternate glyphs, but I didn't see a matching U. I was going to suggest Gill Facia, which has an Alt U that has no stem, but the two sides are not the same weight, and the N doesn't have a full serif. Maybe Renko is right, but the U was fabricated by mirroring the left side of the U.

- Mike Yanega

\> _(â€¦) but the U was fabricated by mirroring the left side of the U._

Yeah, I was wondering about this. Why mirror the U?

For more options in this specific style check these [Trajan Alternatives](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202050153/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/alternatives/trajan/?&sample_text=Q%20U%20I%20N%20C%20E).
